newsitem.title: HONG KONG: Shenzhen B shares end sharply lower on crackdown.
newsitem.headline: Shenzhen B shares end sharply lower on crackdown.

text.p: Shenzhen's B share index fell sharply on Thursday as a result of a new crackdown by securities authorities on mainland Chinese buying B shares, brokers said.
The B index fell 11.23 points, or 6.02 percent, to 175.22 after hitting an intra-session low of 171.07, on turnover of HK$395.77 million, compared with Wednesday's HK$509.83 million.
Of 43 Shenzhen-listed B shares, 41 fell and two rose.

Brokers said that, on orders from the securities authorities, securities firms in Shenzhen have stopped accepting B share trading account applications from domestic investors unless they use funds from outside mainland China.
"Today's retreat could also be seen as the continuation of a technical correction in light of the surge of the index over the past few weeks," the broker said.
"A modest rebound is likely after the steep falls since Tuesday," another broker said.
An official of the Shenzhen Foreign Exchange Management Bureau under the People's Bank of China said that money used to purchase B shares must come from outside mainland China.
"It is illegal for Chinese to buy B shares with foreign currency from within the mainland," he said.
Brokerages know the rules well but some violate them, he added.
"Institutions took the crackdown as an excuse to cash in on the market's recent strong gains," said a broker at Shenzhen J & A Securities.
Weifu, the biggest loser, fell HK$0.90, or 15 percent, to HK$5.10 on volume of 994,300 shares. Southern Glass fell HK$0.82 or 12.11 percent to HK$5.95 on trade of 2.91 million shares.
Changan Automobile traded the most on volume of 7.02 million shares and fell HK$0.60 to HK$5.20 on institutional selling, brokers said.
Building materials producer Fangda bucked the trend, rising HK$0.13 to HK$8.78, with trading of 2.56 million shares.
Refrigerator maker Meilin inched up HK$0.02 to HK$6.70 on the day's second most active trade of 4.64 million shares.
The A market also fell on profit-taking, brokers said.
The A index lost 11.04 points, or 2.22 percent, to 487.41 on turnover of 14.24 billion yuan compared with 14.86 billion in the previous session.
The composite index slumped 11.36 points, or 2.40 percent, to 461.66.
Pharmaceutical issue Yunnan Baiyao plunged 0.86 yuan, or 7.32 percent, to 10.89 yuan.
